Posted: August 3, 2015
												Space Pirates and Zombies appears at first glance nothing more than a retro style, 2d space shooter. But after playing it a lot, multiple playthroughs and challenges, it has a ton of depth lying beneath it's 2d surface.You start as the leader of a small band of merchant pirates yourself seeking your fortune by collecting mineral deposits call rez. There are rumors of enormous stockpiles or rez near the core worlds so you set off to seek them out. Along the way you encounter zombies and eventually take on the gargantuan task of ridding the galaxy of them.The first thing you do is set your world settings. There's multiple difficulty levels, 5 or 6 in total so you can vary your experience immensely, as well as settings for galaxy size, pirate density and tech distribution. You can create a unique experience for every game.Once you are playing the game has three main areas. First is the galaxy and system maps. You travel to different systems and you can select various missions in each one to level up your crew, buy or steal tech and collect rez and ship designs. The systems all have different levels so you have to decide what you can potentially accomplish.The next big part is your ship loadout screens, tech and hangar. In the tech screen you spend data (experience) that you have gather to level up various ship systems like beam weapons or shields. Each level increases the effectiveness of your systems and some levels are a prerequisite to advanced tech. Like you need level three beams to deploy particle beams or something. Then in the hanger you choose which hulls to use and what systems to put on them. You start with three hangars at the beginning of the game and get four by the end with larger capacity for larger hulls.The final major area is actually flying your ships on the planet or area of interest screens. They aren't always combat screens, some missions you might gather rez for example. But while on these screens you can switch control between all your ships as well as issuing orders to the other ships to do certain things like rendezvous over here or attack this target. Sometimes pirates show up, sometimes zombies, all depends on the mission. I found there to be a good variety of events and missions.The actual combat is extremely interesting if you make it challenging enough. Because there are so many types of ships and systems the way you fight can be varied. You might make a fast missile boat ship and whittle targets down while keeping out of their gun range. Or you might make a stealth capable ship, get in close and crush em with high powered beam cutters. Or maybe you want to use rotating turrets to track fast moving targets. It's up to you, there's no wrong way to do it, and a lot of times you have to adjust on the fly based on the tech available.Hull designs are obtained by killing enemy ships of that hull. Sometimes one ship is enough but most need 3 or 4 blueprint pieces. Tech for subsystems like weapons, engines and all that is obtained from planets either by trading with them or blowing up their bases and taking it. There's also specialist crew members who give you distinct bonuses like +10% cannon damage. So that has to be taken into account as well.In all there's a ton of ways to customize your game and your ships and it's very fun. I enjoyed leveling in this game immensely. The only downside is the hardest difficulties are REALLY hard and you end up basically grinding resources in low level areas to advance. But hard should be hard so I commend the devs for doing that. I guess you could fly smarter, not harder, if you're really good and get by with less.Finally there's challenges too via a little space arena the pirates run. It's a good way to make money and there's some achievements with it. Some are very hard.This game simply rocks and you have to try it.

Posted: September 4, 2012
												SPAZ is an amazing game! It is a real-time strategy game where you control a small squadron of spaceships from a 2D top-down perspective. Battles are fought by the player taking direct control of one ship while the other 1-3 ships are AI controlled. Resource management is pretty straight forward- all ships are purchased with "rez" and crewed by "goons" that you either recruit or press into service. Ships are highly customizable. I have only two gripes: The written story dialog is terrible, both poorly written and sometimes confusing, and there is some grinding involved to level-up your ships; though overall, the fun game play, simple to use tactical commands, and customization of the ships makes this game a must have.

Posted: December 20, 2011
												Great indie title that can be approached in a variety of ways. On easier difficulties and on large planetery systems it plays like a Diablo-esque version of Beat Hazard where you grind enemies for research (xp), goons (prisoners) and REZ ($) in order to improve your fleet. On higher difficulties and smaller galaxies you need to approach things more cautiously and you'll need to plan ahead. There are many types of ships that you can unlock by reverse engineering their hulls and each ship can be upgraded with a variety of weapons (rocket launchers, turrets, lazers, drones, etc). The game offers a per-planetery system alliance mechanism, a research system involving  dozens of technologies that directly effect your ships (engine,hull,etc), a trading system, some randomized missions and events. Combat is real time but there's also a pause button/tactical screen. There's more than meets the eye in this one.

Posted: July 2, 2015
												I had a ton of fun with this indie gem.  The game is easy to pick up, but delivers on strategic challenge later on.   The battles are usually fast-paced and enjoyable, with many different valid strategic approaches.  Except for a few technologies that go obsolete, all the equipment you find can be used right up through the endgame, because you can equip small AI-controlled helper ships to help you on missions. I did find that the game was too easy, but I could have raised the difficulty.  Also, sometimes the enemy AI will use a fast ship and simply fly away from you, which it can do indefinitely, making it impossible to complete a mission. Posted: January 11, 2013
												This game is super addictive and fun! Well worth the money.It has an excellent simple to control combat, the difficuly on default normal is just right and I have always felt it's my own fault for not being prepared for a fight or getting in over my head when I've had to retreat. It's also very forgiving of failure, which so far has merely meant licking my wounds and spending a few minutes gathering crew and money. Sometimes by taking my rage out of weaker systems at the same time.The only time I felt I had an unfair loss (I'll skip the mission details, save to say I needed to be stealthy) and the one thing I can point out that actually needs improving is the AI ships on your team that you're not currently controlling will sometimes ignore a "passive" command and fire at enemies anyway when you're trying not to engage. I simply recycled those ships and went solo and succeeded later, then rebuilt the ships again which takes mere seconds afterward.The good number of ship selection and weapons, and the ability to place different weapons or boosters in slots give you a advantage, or occasionally disadvantage, and give a feeling of variety and tactics to the combat. If you choose poorly you needn't fear losing a mission usually, you can go into the "hanger" screen refit your ship(s) and have them warp out and a handfull of seconds later warp back into the map.It has an "rpg" element that you level up and select to upgrade over a dozen types of parts of your ship to work better and be able to equip new things which further gives you a feeling of being in control of your ships.The visuals are very beautiful and colorfull eye candy, but you can see all that in the pictures or youtube vids.

Posted: August 19, 2011
												You're a space pirate out for profit and martial power while navigating a massive, randomly generated galaxy that you can set the size and level of difficulty for.  Blowing stuff up and buying weapon blueprints allow you to reverse engineer better stuff for your personal squad of ships.  There are multiple resources to manage for a wide variety of uses.  As you collect Data, you can invest research into 15 different technology categories to augment your play style.  If you feel you've made poor choices, you can reallocate research... though it causes a reasonable setback.The simplistic design of the game contrasts greatly with its resulting complexity (similar to Chess, but to a much lesser degree).  The amount of freedom is likewise staggering. The  ships, gear, specializations, even the method used to traverse the galaxy, all of this stuff is up to the player.  The very tight controls, thorough balance, and terrifying zombies of course add to the greatness.

Posted: April 22, 2015
												First my profile: 44y, born in France and living in Canada, I am a casual player for the last 25y ( and an adict the first 5y) so I played tons of games from various genre, mostly on PC.I highly recommend this game, mostly because it's fun.I have rarely completed game twice but as I foundly remembered the game, I tried it once more and realized there was a new update that added bounty hunters and realized they re-balanced the game, which likely explain some of the earlier bad score.I somewhat forgot some of the game mechanic but it all came back and I can  say doing it all over again was pure joy.The game has a good mix of strategy, story telling, action and progression.I love to pilote a small fleet and the many options to go about the difficult missions. Some complain the difficulty curve is too high, especially in mid-game, but I would say that it is a welcome challenge as the AI is quite weak and they are many ways to exploit it. There is a bit of grinding but I kind of like it myself being a bit perfectionist with games and liking to explore all there is to see and find secrets so be warned.It's a two man game and I find that inspiring, those guys have talents and I can't wait to put my hand on SPAZ 2 when it comes out.THe graphics are not for everyone but I personally like it and 2D worked for piloting the ships.The music was repetitive but pleasant and I did not get tired of it. I find music can play a bit part of your long term memory of the joy of playing a game and this one is still lingering in my subconcient.Overall a 9/10 for me.

												Definitely unique, the art is nothing to write home about but blasting through blockade after blockade is fun.For the first handful of times anyway. There is a perpetual grind in this game that really, REALLY grates after twelve hours.It is fun! For a while. Looking past that, it is a good title I recommend. Posted: January 7, 2015
												SPAZ is a top-down space grinder. You start with almost nothing and build your way up to the commander of a squad of ships. As you complete story missions, you gain access to larger hangars which means larger ships to command. You can manipulate your enemies and scavange their ships after they've destroyed one another. You can eradicate infections and undermine the local rebellion or authority figures. Pros-Fun! Collecting the various weapons and tools, then customized your ships to find the best combinations is hours of enjoyment.Unique! Not many games I've played have the variety of units and unpredictability of SPAZ. I've seen ships that shouldn't have succeeded destroy others that are twice their size.Cons-Wash, Rinse, Repeat- A bit repetitive at times. Requires lots of time grinding to find the blueprints for all the ships. Not always the most fun, but it DOES make getting your first HUGE ship so rewarding.Angry? Have some Goons- Very easy to manipulate the factions by bribing them with goons (a sort of influence currency). Once you're on their good sides, you can just wait for them to butt heads and collect the cash, goons, data, and blueprints left over from their conflicts. Not super challenging.Braaaaaaains- The Zombies are very unique and sometimes absurdly over powered. Still need to get used to them, but their initial strategies require you to change your thinking ALOT.9/10 BUY IT (ESPECIALLY IF IT'S ON SALE)

Posted: August 17, 2012
												The game is hands down one of the best indie games I have played in the past few years, easily in my top 5 indie games when you consider it's "fun factor". The graphics are very pleasing especially for a cartoon look. The sound fit's the game well as does the artwork. SPAZ has several difficulty settings ranging from "casual just play for fun and never lose" to "please just kill me now". On it's most difficult setting even the most experienced gamers will be tested. The galaxy can be created relatively small (still very large offering many hours of gameplay) to massive offering literally hundreds of hours of play time. The map is also randomly generated so replay value is high. Bounty Hunters (free DLC) adds a fourth faction to interact with adding new ways to explore or destroy star systems!All in all a highly suggested purchase that will offer something to all gamers, casual and hardcore alike.

												The universe you know of is endangered by some unknown biological threat.As a military recruit you are set out to investigate this. Along the way all is not what it seems to be.I had a lot of fun with this one:- Beautiful colorful graphics & some nice space (contamination) effects- Believable space environments & sounds- Fleet, vessel, weapons & systems customization- Fun & sometimes hard battles, depending on your system & mission selection- Side with the military, the rebels or the pirates per system you are in- Get a bounty your head by the Bounty Hunters & fight them off to get some special ship plans or systems upgrades- Fight in the Bounty Hunters arena- Zombies in space - avoid infection!- Various but at the same time same-ish missions to choose from- Some experience grinding is required to reach your goals- Thus be prepared to waste a lot of time to finish it- Weak & easy ending. Posted: April 13, 2012
												This game is a rare indy gem, unlike most indie gems, this game has more gameplay in it than most games released these days. The story is laughable and hard to follow, something about upgrading your mothership and getting a laser or something, but it does take a pretty unexpected twist in the fourth act. The meat of the game is VERY customizable ship combat. Outfit your increasingly powerful ships with lasers, cannons, missles, fighter drones, and more. The combat is great too, the Shield/Hull defences vs. Lasers/Projectiles mechanic requires carefull weapon loadouts, and as long as you keep your less than stellar AI comrades under a good leash, even overwhelming odds can be handled with skill. Also, SPAZ is made by a two-man team who are just doing what they love, and buying this game helps them make the game better. SPAZ has added HUGE amounts of content since launch (Namely the Bounty Hunters) and will keep having content added if people keep supporting it.

Posted: July 22, 2012
												Now of course there is room for improvement but it does so many things well. The battles are fun, intense and usually pretty challenging. The management elements have depth and require thought and skill but aren't as daunting as you would expect. Un-lockable hull types with the ability to customize those hulls, weapons, shields and more. A very pretty game graphically, especially for an indie game with a 2 man development team. I've spent time just watching the A.I. battles that play in the background on the main menu screen. Now the ship controls can feel a little odd at first but once you get used to them they make sense. In short, if you have any interest in space battles and fun sci fi stories you have to own this game. I love it and have bought multiple copies for my friends. Good luck and I hope you enjoy it as much as I do.

Posted: August 30, 2012
												SPAZ... oh SPAZ, how i love you... Space Pirates and Zombies is a game that deserve... Nein! It NEEDS more attention. Its a great game made by 2 great dudes. They are working (slowly) on SPAZ 2.I really have nothing, nothing bad to say about this game. The trailer they got is a great way to show off how to game works, what you see is what you get. So if you like what you see then buy it, its a great game.Here's what i think of the game. The game is a fun little game where you fly around with a small fleet of spaceship. You have a mothership that you can't control and it rebuilds and refit all your spaceships to your need. You start of with only one ship, and gain the ability to use other ships by destroying that type of ship, once destroyed the ship drops a blueprint, collect them to unlock the ship for yourself. The larger the ship, the more blueprints you need. So a small fighter might only need two pieces of that blueprint, destroy 2, collect the blueprint and the fighter is yours. While cruisers and battleships might need up to 8 blueprints, and they usally have alot more health and are harder to kill.You also get the ability to refit your ships with weapons you want to use. Each ship has its own number of hardpoints, you can mix and match and put whatever you want on your ship. Want to fire kinetic rounds? sure. Lasers? Why not. Plasma balls? It's your ship, your rules.Now this might be a minor spoiler but they got it in the title of the game so... Story goes that you are a space pirate, each solar system is cut off from each other so what you do in one system won't carry over to the next. To get to another system (a higher leveled one with more advanced ships) you'll have to fight through a UTA Blockade, they block access to the warpgates you need access to procedd in the game, either destroy them all or bribe them to give you access. Each system has 2 factions. The UTA (Military, always blocks the warpgates with blockades). And the Civvies, they control mining and science operations in deep space and usally let you use their facility freely (So you can mine resource, et.c.). You will randomly get a faction rating in each starsystem, sometimes they love you from the start, sometimes they hate you. You'll never know. Pick your side, start blasting ships from the oppossite side and soon you'll make some great friends in that starsystem.Later on in the game Zombie ships start to appear, and near the end of the game they will be your main enemy. The UTA and Civvies notice the major zombie problem and team up together with you to reclaim the galaxy from the zombies. Zombie ships are unique ships that you can not unlock. They consist of two type of ships, fighting type ships that look like infected normal ships. They will engage anyone mindlessly. And then we got the breed type ships that look like human bodyparts of some sort. They infect ships without shields, if your ship gets infected you have little time to react, either self destruct your ship so the zombies can't gain control of it and use it against you... or make the hard choice and vent the ship of all crew except the captain, so the infection can't spread. It's a hard job late game, but someone has to purge the galaxy from the zombies.There is also a fourth faction that was released freely with the game. And they are the Bounty Hunters. There ships are unique with specific traits and are also very, very over powered. If you go around in a starsystem they "control" and wreck havoc, you will start to lose respect with them. Lose to much of it and they will warp in when you least want it (in a difficult fight with another faction) and try to blow you out of the space, for the most part they succedd with this. One of the hardest achivements ingame want's you to destroy their space station in the hardest type of starsystem.So will you use standard weapons like lasers, kinetic rounds or plasma to destroy your enemies? or will you go for missiles and torpedos instead? Why not use EMP weapons and energy drainers to drain all energy from your enemy ships so they can't fire their weapons or escape? Nukes? Sure, SPAZ has them. Drones for carriers, that too. There is alot to do with this game, and it gave me alot of hours of fun.The only three really bad parts about this game are:Interface dosen't look very professional.The story isen't that good, it had one somewhat good plot twist in it tho.The last "part" of the game, the "purge" all galaxy of zombie threat's is a repeative and somewhat boring job to do. Everything before that is fun tho.

												Surprisingly this is a very good indie game, one of the best I've played.This is a real-time space shooter game that has some RPG and strategy elements in it. Combined together, it is actually a very addictive game that keeps you playing. You can have a fleet of up to 4 ships, and with it you gather resources, unlock new ships and technology, level up for talent points, trade with the 2 factions in the game to become more powerful. You can help or hinder either of the two factions, and the number of ships they can field in battle will increase or decrease, making your actions influence the galaxy.The graphics, sound and story are decent enough, but the game-play is top notch.As of this recommendation, the game is good enough despite being simple. But it could be so much more and the developers plan to add more content. If you have some spare change, consider buying it during a sale and help fund the sequel, SPAZ 2.

Posted: December 27, 2011
												SPAZ is a great arcade space shooter / RPG with a mouthful of a name.  It contains exactly what it says: space pirates and zombies.  You explore the galaxy, dealing with different factions, doing missions to level up and increase the size and power of your fleet.  The ships handle very well and are very customizable.  Friendly and enemy AI is very competent and can make the game quite challenging, depending on the skill level you set.The one large problem I ran into with the game was pacing.  I ended up having to spend pretty lengthy amounts of time searching for the appropriate level systems to do missions in in order to level up in order to continue the story or move into a particular system that was several levels higher than me.Other than that though, the game is quite fun and a bit of a challenge.  It was worth it, despite all the extra time I had to put in.

Posted: October 6, 2014
												I got this on sale thinking I might get an afternoon out of it but I got so much more.  One thing I noticed, this game has an addiction factor much like the civilization games. Every mission you do makes you want to push on to see what's next, got to get that next ship or that next weapon. GRAPHICS: are very detailed for a 2D game and throw out some nice effects, for example the explosions are pretty decent with bits being blasted off as you bring down a ship slowly, crew being sucked out of a breach in the hull and there are some rather nice backdrops with small details you can appreciate when you zoom in. SOUND:  isn't overbearing, there is an effect for everything but it just lacks a little punch for my tastes.  I would have liked the weapons to sound a bit meatier, right now they sound like pings and pops. The explosions however do sound pretty good when you blow up something big. There is some interesting and funny radio chatter that will put a smile on your face. MUSIC: very much suits a game of this type, it doesn't try to overshadow the sound effects or deafen you when you're in a firefight...which is almost always. It's the kind of music that sticks in your head when you're not playing the game. Your currencies are well balanced and you never have too much, you will of course always run out but then there's always a way to make back the lost currency, unlike a lot of games where you have way too much money and nothing to spend it on, I really do hate that in a lot of games. I'm blown away by how addicting this game is without feeling like it's a sugar rush. What I mean is that it won't give you all of the cool stuff in the first 5 minutes of the game and then you have to grind for another 50 hours without anything awesome to discover. No, this game is one of the best paced games I've ever played and the balance of leveling, tech points and weapon acquisition over the course of the entire game will give you the feeling that you ate the whole cake, not just a bunch of icing or just the cake without icing.....if you catch my drift. At the time of this review, I've clocked 45 hours but I'm still having a blast, still have a lot to discover and upgrade but at the same time I kinda don't want to finish this game. You know something is good when you want it to go on. I just hope SPAZ 2 has that same feeling....

Posted: January 19, 2015
												This is probably the grindiest game I've ever played. It's not a bad game at all, but it has a few hours of fun gameplay spread out over 25 hours repeating the same missions over and over. There's no real reason to explore systems, especially if you don't need a technology upgrade. A little blip of story in random systems or random FTL-style encounter would make it more compelling to explore.The devs in the forums confirm that the best way to play is to put all of your points into one type of weapon. If you don't, you'll have to grind 2-3x as much to viably use multiple types of weapons. Despite all the fancy looking weapons, attachments, and mounting points in this game, you'll probably end up with a ship loaded with all of one type of weapon. You'll also quickly learn to never die so much that you run out of rez, or you'll have to grind away at a mining station for a while just to have enough money to start playing the game again.If I played again, I would play without bounty hunters. It looks like they a balancing mechanism, because the only thing they do is provide a constant drain on your resources. The diminishing returns of their arena-style missions weren't very worthwhile.It does look very good, especially when battles involve different kinds of ships, weapons, and drones flying about. The movement and turning speed plays a major role in the game, so I did like how I feels like naval warfare. Throughout the 25 hours there were fun bits unlocking new ships and figuring out what works well too, but once I figured it out it was back to the grind. It's a decent game to play while watching TV or listening to some podcasts, but it wouldn't hold my interest alone.

Posted: July 7, 2013
												Played this game for about a week now. I find it enjoyable and challenging even though it gets a little repetitive after while. You are always a step behind in ships but you can upgrade your weapons, shields, armor, etc before the enemy. Early ships are given to you once you beat it in battle. The smaller ships are done in one battle. As you get to larger ships you have to beat the same type ship from twice to, well I am at level 54 and I have beaten some ships 4 times already and I am only at 80% reverse engineered for that ship type.  You always have ways of getting Spaz (money) to spend, sometimes quickly other times you have to work for it. As you move up to higher levels the battles get more intense and are fun. Right now I have three ships on Level 54 the enemy might start with 4 or 5 then as you beat them they warp in a few more with one a little bigger than what you have sometimes. In between battles you can upgrade and find Spaz. The universe is quite larger with higher levels as you get to the inside systems. I just made it to the Zombie level and came back to upgrade more. I was no where near leveled up enough to stay there.I now have played the game twice. Very repetitive all the way through the game. Same thing in each system just as you level up you have more ships to beat, then the Bounty Hunters start showing up right after or during a battle making it that much harder to beat that level. Very long game to beat. Bounty Hunter Challenges are fun.

Posted: June 30, 2014
												Space Pirates and Zombies. Remember Starscape? This feels a lot like a very well-done and much-improved sequal to Starscape. You fly around different space zones collecting resources that you use to upgrade your mothership, unlock new fighter chassis and build fighters.So how does it hold up? I think very well. A word about control: Don't bother without a mouse. Personally, there are very few games that require both mouse and keyboard that I will play with a laptop touchpad. This is not one of them. It's a very twitchy game, and the awkwardness of having one hand under my other wrist and having to click both buttons with my thumb is just too clumsy for me.The graphics are fun. The fighter/shuttle designs are different enough to be interesting, and the effects are flashy enough to be from a JJ Abrams movie.They make a half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥attempt at realistic physics, which is not really the rule with space games. That is to say: inertia is a thing, but not the infinite thing that it really ought to be. If you cut your engines, you will keep going but eventually stop. Is it always impressive when a game DOES have realistic physics? Yup. Is it always fun? Nope.  To that point, SPAZ makes it fun.

Posted: November 26, 2016
												What a game, what a work of art for a two-person team.It's so beautiful, from the debris-strewn starscapes to the twinkling spaceships and spinning starbases. The sound effects are good, too. The background chatter could have used more variety, but it was so well done and unobstrusive that it never annoyed me. The misanthropic humor is pervasive throughout the game, from the main characters' dialogue to the way slavery is tacitly endorsed by everyone.There are lots intriguing ships, weapons, and upgrades to try, though brute-force lasering was how I usually settled things. The beams-cannons-missiles damage system makes you carefully weigh your strengths and weaknesses, while the rez-goons-data economy keeps you hunting for ways to exploit and score. I would have liked more missions and factions, though.The difficulty of the game is quite well balanced until the very end. I got stuck many times, but getting unstuck often required just a different fleet or loadout. And when I needed a break, I could look for other things to do like collect components or free up warp gates.Still, the game is undeniably a grind. With there being only two factions and not much in the way of plot and missions, there is a lot of looking for other things to do. When the game got too repetitive, I'd play it intensely for a few weeks and then stop for a few months before playing again.What bothers me most is how the game ended. In the last chapter, I did the minimum I had to do to proceed to the finale. I then saved the game and went ahead to the finale just to take a brief peek at it, expecting to be defeated right away. Fifteen minutes later, I'd won the game without breaking a sweat. That was really disappointing. I was playing on Normal difficulty with a tech level of 113, so I don't think I was overleveled. In fact, the unique side missions were still very tough for me. Even the story, which I found fairly interesting, ended flatly.

Posted: November 26, 2016
												Don't let the stupid name put you off (as it did me), SPAZ is an awesome game. Check the demo to see for yourself.The game is a top down space ship fleet combat shooter. You design ships using modular components such as hulls, weapons, engines and other support systems that you unlock as you go. You can have multiple ships in your fleet but you only control one ship at a time with the ability to switch control to any combat ship in your fleet. You can give basic instructions to your other AI controlled ships via a tactical interface. Story wise it's pretty simplistic, with the occasional bit of juvenile humour. You travel around the galaxy gaining favour in star systems in order to unlock new technologies and access to services and resources.

Posted: January 11, 2013
												This game is super addictive and fun! Well worth the money.It has an excellent simple to control combat, the difficuly on default normal is just right and I have always felt it's my own fault for not being prepared for a fight or getting in over my head when I've had to retreat. It's also very forgiving of failure, which so far has merely meant licking my wounds and spending a few minutes gathering crew and money. Sometimes by taking my rage out of weaker systems at the same time.The only time I felt I had an unfair loss (I'll skip the mission details, save to say I needed to be stealthy) and the one thing I can point out that actually needs improving is the AI ships on your team that you're not currently controlling will sometimes ignore a "passive" command and fire at enemies anyway when you're trying not to engage. I simply recycled those ships and went solo and succeeded later, then rebuilt the ships again which takes mere seconds afterward.The good number of ship selection and weapons, and the ability to place different weapons or boosters in slots give you a advantage, or occasionally disadvantage, and give a feeling of variety and tactics to the combat. If you choose poorly you needn't fear losing a mission usually, you can go into the "hanger" screen refit your ship(s) and have them warp out and a handfull of seconds later warp back into the map.It has an "rpg" element that you level up and select to upgrade over a dozen types of parts of your ship to work better and be able to equip new things which further gives you a feeling of being in control of your ships.The visuals are very beautiful and colorfull eye candy, but you can see all that in the pictures or youtube vids.

Posted: January 3, 2012
												Now here's a game that quietly passed underneath my radar. I thought it was going to be too strategy based for my liking, but there isn't a whole lot of strategy to it. It's more like a casual space exploration game that integrates action based combat. As you progress, the battles can get pretty intense, but there's no pressure because you don't lose the game if you lose a battle allowing you to experiment and move at your own pace. Usually you just have to reassess your ship configurations if you get into a situation you can't handle.There is a slight learning curve, but nothing overwhelming. The galaxy is very large providing hundreds of hours of potential play and the game always seems to throw you a new challenge as you advance, so it doesn't get repetitively boring. There's plenty to do between the main story mission, side missions, and the variety of faction objectives in each system. Hands down, SPAZ is a game that should be in your collection.

Posted: January 8, 2012
												Surprisingly this is a very good indie game, one of the best I've played.This is a real-time space shooter game that has some RPG and strategy elements in it. Combined together, it is actually a very addictive game that keeps you playing. You can have a fleet of up to 4 ships, and with it you gather resources, unlock new ships and technology, level up for talent points, trade with the 2 factions in the game to become more powerful. You can help or hinder either of the two factions, and the number of ships they can field in battle will increase or decrease, making your actions influence the galaxy.The graphics, sound and story are decent enough, but the game-play is top notch.As of this recommendation, the game is good enough despite being simple. But it could be so much more and the developers plan to add more content. If you have some spare change, consider buying it during a sale and help fund the sequel, SPAZ 2.

Posted: September 11, 2012
												This was a pleasant surprise of a space sim, in which the focus is as much on the 2D top-down space combat as it is on resource collection, faction negotiation/manipulation, and technology collection. It has a very RPG feel - as you gain experience and level, you place points into the systems of your ship that you most rely on, forcing you to always evaluate your strategy as there are MANY different systems to put points into, and the ships that you receive all use them differently. I did not expect to get sucked into this game, nor did I expect it to last as long as it did. Be careful with this one - it can get addictive very quickly. And once you get going, it's going to carry you a lot longer than you'll expect. It does get too repetitive towards the end of the game, and a lot of that time was spent grinding out materials. 3 out of 5 foxes.

Posted: December 4, 2013
												SPAZ, where to begin with this game?It is fun, perhaps not as intuitive as could be, interactive, perhaps sometimes montonous, especially on the first play-through when 'rez' farming becomes a regular occurence as countless little ships of yours get blasted into the dark abyss of space. It's design features and artistic styling leaves little to be desired; there truly is something for everything in this game! The faction system appears bleak, with the UTA, CIV, and Bounty Hunters not being fully exploited to their potential; the game uses the excuse that different star-systems don't communicate, and as such your reputation is reset to a set level in each system, a much better idea could be to have an option of this, but also a ranking system within a faction. Right now 'respect' is the only obtainable quantity with a faction (BH), and even that has miniscule effects on the game.The personalised feel to the game is something that draws you in and, more importantly, makes you want to stay. This game is so engaging, I can see myself losing countless more hours to it! I highly recommend this game, and though the £6.99 price tag may at first appear quite steep, believe me, the hours of fun you will get out of this game makes it all worthwhile.

												Top down space shooter with an addictive progression system. It feels like a 2D Freelancer flying around upgrading ships, blowing up pirates, civilians, zombies, police cruisers all the while upgrading your little band of mercenary ships makes for an absolutely fantastic time. Combat is fluid and each ship handles a little differently as a space game should. All this made by two people. Weapon and ship upgrades keep the player going for 'just a bit longer' into the wee hours of next week.Get it, play it, love it.

												This game is a great mesh of the space strategy and space shooter genera's. Like most space games, you start out in a dinky bucket of bolts, and then work your way up to better ships. The main twist is that you get to create a small fleet of ships, which you can then fly into combat. During combat, you can switch between any of the ships in your fleet at will. 												This game is a wonderful blend of action, role playing, and horror elements.You are part of a crew trying to get rich in the universe while generally aiding the local police/military forces (UTA) or rebels trying to shut them down (Civ). The entire game revolves around you doing pretty much whatever you want, but never making that easy.The variety of ships is sure to appeal to pretty much everyone (Carriers, Battleships, Gunboats, and even a few cargo vessels) and the combat and ship customization is very, very well done.

Posted: December 28, 2011
												Watch the trailer. If you like what you see, buy it. SPAZ is simply THE best game of it's genre, touching upon all the niche's and features that you might think to add to a top-down space exploration shmup. The Bounty Hunters update added a half dozen more ships and a ton of (voluntary) challenge scenarios.My biggest complaint: the second chapter (four chapters total) is rather long if you're a completionist and want to unlock everything. A lot of people stop playing prematurely and never enter the third chapter, where the zombies appear in earnest.Also: play on a medium sized galaxy. In a small galaxy the level gap between stars can be too large and you'll run out of things to do in a system, and you're more screwed if you♥♥♥♥♥♥off the wrong faction in a particular system. In a huge galaxy there's too many systems between you and wherever you want to go, so it gets repetitive.

Posted: February 28, 2016
												I purchased SPAZ on a whim; it's not the type of game I usually play but, more importantly, it's not the sort of game I actively avoid either.To get the criticisms out of the way first, SPAZ has a fairly steep and unforgiving learning curve. Attempting to quickly punch through warp gates and advance the story will end in complete destruction. Lengthy and repetitive grinding sessions are required in order to keep your tech levels high enough to survive.That said, SPAZ is insanely addictive, fun and the payoffs are worth it. What could be better than more, bigger and better ships?... and that's even before the zombies come into play.I definitely can't wait for SPAZ 2.

												Its a grinder pure and simple. Story line is about as stupid and weak as you would expect. The missions are hack and slash rinse and repeat ad nauseum. There is a great feel to the game but the content can only support about an hour or two of game play. Still its a reminiscent isometric game and nostalgia has a high value for some even if it is by definition repetitive. Overall I'd rate the game 3/10.

Posted: January 19, 2015
												This is probably the grindiest game I've ever played. It's not a bad game at all, but it has a few hours of fun gameplay spread out over 25 hours repeating the same missions over and over. There's no real reason to explore systems, especially if you don't need a technology upgrade. A little blip of story in random systems or random FTL-style encounter would make it more compelling to explore.The devs in the forums confirm that the best way to play is to put all of your points into one type of weapon. If you don't, you'll have to grind 2-3x as much to viably use multiple types of weapons. Despite all the fancy looking weapons, attachments, and mounting points in this game, you'll probably end up with a ship loaded with all of one type of weapon. You'll also quickly learn to never die so much that you run out of rez, or you'll have to grind away at a mining station for a while just to have enough money to start playing the game again.If I played again, I would play without bounty hunters. It looks like they a balancing mechanism, because the only thing they do is provide a constant drain on your resources. The diminishing returns of their arena-style missions weren't very worthwhile.It does look very good, especially when battles involve different kinds of ships, weapons, and drones flying about. The movement and turning speed plays a major role in the game, so I did like how I feels like naval warfare. Throughout the 25 hours there were fun bits unlocking new ships and figuring out what works well too, but once I figured it out it was back to the grind. It's a decent game to play while watching TV or listening to some podcasts, but it wouldn't hold my interest alone.

Although many aspects are quite antiquated, the combat system is its redeaming factor, and is the primary focus of the game. Posted: January 7, 2015
												SPAZ is a top-down space grinder. You start with almost nothing and build your way up to the commander of a squad of ships. As you complete story missions, you gain access to larger hangars which means larger ships to command. You can manipulate your enemies and scavange their ships after they've destroyed one another. You can eradicate infections and undermine the local rebellion or authority figures. Pros-Fun! Collecting the various weapons and tools, then customized your ships to find the best combinations is hours of enjoyment.Unique! Not many games I've played have the variety of units and unpredictability of SPAZ. I've seen ships that shouldn't have succeeded destroy others that are twice their size.Cons-Wash, Rinse, Repeat- A bit repetitive at times. Requires lots of time grinding to find the blueprints for all the ships. Not always the most fun, but it DOES make getting your first HUGE ship so rewarding.Angry? Have some Goons- Very easy to manipulate the factions by bribing them with goons (a sort of influence currency). Once you're on their good sides, you can just wait for them to butt heads and collect the cash, goons, data, and blueprints left over from their conflicts. Not super challenging.Braaaaaaains- The Zombies are very unique and sometimes absurdly over powered. Still need to get used to them, but their initial strategies require you to change your thinking ALOT.9/10 BUY IT (ESPECIALLY IF IT'S ON SALE)

Posted: August 3, 2015
												Space Pirates and Zombies appears at first glance nothing more than a retro style, 2d space shooter. But after playing it a lot, multiple playthroughs and challenges, it has a ton of depth lying beneath it's 2d surface.You start as the leader of a small band of merchant pirates yourself seeking your fortune by collecting mineral deposits call rez. There are rumors of enormous stockpiles or rez near the core worlds so you set off to seek them out. Along the way you encounter zombies and eventually take on the gargantuan task of ridding the galaxy of them.The first thing you do is set your world settings. There's multiple difficulty levels, 5 or 6 in total so you can vary your experience immensely, as well as settings for galaxy size, pirate density and tech distribution. You can create a unique experience for every game.Once you are playing the game has three main areas. First is the galaxy and system maps. You travel to different systems and you can select various missions in each one to level up your crew, buy or steal tech and collect rez and ship designs. The systems all have different levels so you have to decide what you can potentially accomplish.The next big part is your ship loadout screens, tech and hangar. In the tech screen you spend data (experience) that you have gather to level up various ship systems like beam weapons or shields. Each level increases the effectiveness of your systems and some levels are a prerequisite to advanced tech. Like you need level three beams to deploy particle beams or something. Then in the hanger you choose which hulls to use and what systems to put on them. You start with three hangars at the beginning of the game and get four by the end with larger capacity for larger hulls.The final major area is actually flying your ships on the planet or area of interest screens. They aren't always combat screens, some missions you might gather rez for example. But while on these screens you can switch control between all your ships as well as issuing orders to the other ships to do certain things like rendezvous over here or attack this target. Sometimes pirates show up, sometimes zombies, all depends on the mission. I found there to be a good variety of events and missions.The actual combat is extremely interesting if you make it challenging enough. Because there are so many types of ships and systems the way you fight can be varied. You might make a fast missile boat ship and whittle targets down while keeping out of their gun range. Or you might make a stealth capable ship, get in close and crush em with high powered beam cutters. Or maybe you want to use rotating turrets to track fast moving targets. It's up to you, there's no wrong way to do it, and a lot of times you have to adjust on the fly based on the tech available.Hull designs are obtained by killing enemy ships of that hull. Sometimes one ship is enough but most need 3 or 4 blueprint pieces. Tech for subsystems like weapons, engines and all that is obtained from planets either by trading with them or blowing up their bases and taking it. There's also specialist crew members who give you distinct bonuses like +10% cannon damage. So that has to be taken into account as well.In all there's a ton of ways to customize your game and your ships and it's very fun. I enjoyed leveling in this game immensely. The only downside is the hardest difficulties are REALLY hard and you end up basically grinding resources in low level areas to advance. But hard should be hard so I commend the devs for doing that. I guess you could fly smarter, not harder, if you're really good and get by with less.Finally there's challenges too via a little space arena the pirates run. It's a good way to make money and there's some achievements with it. Some are very hard.This game simply rocks and you have to try it.

Posted: July 2, 2015
												I had a ton of fun with this indie gem.  The game is easy to pick up, but delivers on strategic challenge later on.   The battles are usually fast-paced and enjoyable, with many different valid strategic approaches.  Except for a few technologies that go obsolete, all the equipment you find can be used right up through the endgame, because you can equip small AI-controlled helper ships to help you on missions. I did find that the game was too easy, but I could have raised the difficulty.  Also, sometimes the enemy AI will use a fast ship and simply fly away from you, which it can do indefinitely, making it impossible to complete a mission.  This means that you may have to repeat a few missions for no other reason than that.  If you want a multiplayer experience, hold off and buy SPAZ 2, as this one unfortunately lacks that feature.

Posted: July 25, 2015
												This game is 90% great and 10% rubbish.  Its great when everything is going smoothly and you're rampaging around the galaxy killing stuff and its terrible when you get a certain map with an AI ship (in one of the fastest ships in the game) that shoots at you for a bit then runs off when it is near death, then comes back and shoots you again before running off.  When you have done this for 10 mins straight you will hate this game as much as I do - however, with a bit of patience you will realise that you can re-fit your ships mid-match to allow you to catch the tricky bugger or use drones which are faster than most ships.  .

Posted: July 27, 2015
												My only issues were...Pacing:  It felt like it took forever to upgrade the mothership and I ended up using the same ships for hours.  Also if  you need resources it's kind of a grind to accumulate them.  And the upgrade system kind of keeps you locked with regard to what weapons you use.  Switching to a different weapon type costs you all of the upgrade bonuses which typically doesn't work.Saving the game: If you get invaded when going to the mothership to save, you could be forced to fight another 10-15 minutes of ships and reinforcements before you can save the game.  I just ended up getting bored of playing and quit without saving.

Posted: December 29, 2011
												Space Pirats and Zombies is a fantastic achievement in of itself.  Its in the same vein as the old Star Control games in that it features an entirely "Top Down" perspective space combat experience. Despite what may seem like a straight forward simple game at first glance will quickly be washed away by how massive the galaxy can be if you so choose.SPAZ sports an intuitive levelling system where you earn points to spend on research to boost the attributes of several systems of your ships. From shields to turrets to the crew itself, the inner workings of your vessels will be fine tuned as you grow. Where you choose to research also determines what higher quality systems you will be able to implement as you acquire various blueprints for more efficient arms and armors. I would highly recommend this game to any and all who enjoy space combat. Its very action packed and exciting, at least in my opinion.It is truly the triumph of a motivated two man development team!

Posted: October 5, 2012
												I really enjoyed this 2D space game.  I put in about 25-30 hours of casual gameplay into this game before I finally decided to run through to the end.The basic idea is to level up, upgrade skills, and move to higher leveled solar systems.  Doing story missions or misc missions each solar system has.  There is no end to the basic solar system quests.You unlock ships and weapons by killing them or buying them. 												This game is pretty badass. It has the perfect combination of Twitch Skill, Tactical Manuvering, and RPG-like progression. Posted: January 30, 2012
												Es gibt einige Spiele die ich für mich als einige der besten Games der letzten Jahre bezeichnen würde. Dazu gehören viele Indietitel wie Torchlight, Braid, Capsized, Darwinia, Terraria, Minecraft und Defense Grid. SPAZ (Space Pirates and Zombies) wird sich nahtlos in diese Reihe von Top-Indiegames einfügen. Das Spielprinzip ist absolut suchterzeugend, die Mischung aus Action, Strategie und RPG- Elementen ist absolut motivierend. Wäre SPAZ mit einer guten 3D Engine unter einem bekannten Publisher erschienen, wäre dieses Spiel sicherlich viel teurer. Erfolgreicher wäre es deshalb aber auch nicht. Der Developer Minmax Games besteht aus nur 2 Leuten die das Game in 2 Jahren in Eigenregie entwickelt haben. Ich kann nur sagen: Wer sich SPAZ zulegt hat für sehr wenig Geld sehr viel geniales Spielprinzip gekauft und noch mehr Spielspaß!

Posted: January 27, 2012
												Edit: 1/10/2016   This game is still a blast to play. Get it and look forward to SPAZ 2!----First things first, one of the devs of this game gave away a bunch of keys for free on Reddit. Just to be nice! That's quite the act of kindness coming from a very small Independent game. However, I did not receive a key. Instead, I purchased the game since it was available for $3.99 as a weekend deal. I sat down with it once it downloaded, poured me a spot of Scotch, and started playing. Seven hours (!) later I realize that it was now quite early in the morning and I still found myself thinking "Just one more mission". This is easily one of the most satisfying Indie games in my library. Addicting, colorful, witty, and overall killer experience.I suggest picking this up at any price, a stellar title with some down-to-earth developers.

Posted: May 30, 2015
												S.P.A.Z (Space Pirates and Zombies) is a top down arcade, tactical space battle simulator/ RPG.I did little proof reading of this review, it took a while to write and I’m not up to the task atmTo nail some key points,Good - The ships are very well done in design (both balancing and stylistic) but get a bit blurry when zoomed in fully (especially noticeable with the largest class of ship).  - The map is random generated along with most of side missions - The actually "arenas" or player maps where your battles take place look very well done but may get little generic over time although not that noticeable - All the weapons and subsystem special effects are very well done for the top down look - Weapon balancing is a kinda weird at times and falls down into what you prefer / best for the situation - Cookie Famous "Total Biscuit" voice acts the story transitions within this game  - Stupid space humor both live and embed within missions + the story - THE PERFECT GAME for listening to all your music in a very long playlist (be sure to set it for you still can hear the sounds effects and the space humor I mention earlier>Side Note: I will give u music to listen to if your playlist is lacking in contentMixed - You control 1 ship and the rest are set on a the default AI autopilot unless you change how they would react to you and enemies via the tactics menu BUT you can jump freely between ships at any time at a press of a button^ going with this the AI settings in my experience DO NOT remain set when change and switch to the default most prefer mode after each battle/map/mission   (I assume this is to keep you from making a mistake while in battle, but there is no way to lock it. - Zombies do not come until mid game - This game has allot of playtime and becomes a grind Bad - Due to the nature of OpenGL if you tab out of the game while loading assets will be misplaced within the game and looks very distorted unless you restart the game entirelyNow for the giant section no-one I know reads (these review are set to friends only to prevent myself from being barraged with people telling me♥♥♥♥♥♥instead of writing their own opinion)  WHERE IT WENT?!!---->http://puu.sh/i5zkd/2917c27b3f.txtI somehow passsed the review character limit so this is my bypassConclusion: Get this game if you’re into the whole Space combat dealio but be warn at the length of this game can become unbearable at times. Other than that it’s a good game with a sequel underway

Posted: January 26, 2012
												Good game, currently on sale for 4 bucks.Pros: Fun fast paced shooter, fun to customize different ships and upgrade tech.Cons: Only single player, excitement dulls as sometimes you have to grind through several non-challenging stars for resources or to reach an objective.

Posted: September 11, 2012
												This was a pleasant surprise of a space sim, in which the focus is as much on the 2D top-down space combat as it is on resource collection, faction negotiation/manipulation, and technology collection. It has a very RPG feel - as you gain experience and level, you place points into the systems of your ship that you most rely on, forcing you to always evaluate your strategy as there are MANY different systems to put points into, and the ships that you receive all use them differently. I did not expect to get sucked into this game, nor did I expect it to last as long as it did. Be careful with this one - it can get addictive very quickly. And once you get going, it's going to carry you a lot longer than you'll expect. It does get too repetitive towards the end of the game, and a lot of that time was spent grinding out materials. 3 out of 5 foxes.

Posted: December 4, 2013
												SPAZ, where to begin with this game?It is fun, perhaps not as intuitive as could be, interactive, perhaps sometimes montonous, especially on the first play-through when 'rez' farming becomes a regular occurence as countless little ships of yours get blasted into the dark abyss of space. It's design features and artistic styling leaves little to be desired; there truly is something for everything in this game! The faction system appears bleak, with the UTA, CIV, and Bounty Hunters not being fully exploited to their potential; the game uses the excuse that different star-systems don't communicate, and as such your reputation is reset to a set level in each system, a much better idea could be to have an option of this, but also a ranking system within a faction. Right now 'respect' is the only obtainable quantity with a faction (BH), and even that has miniscule effects on the game.The personalised feel to the game is something that draws you in and, more importantly, makes you want to stay. This game is so engaging, I can see myself losing countless more hours to it! I highly recommend this game, and though the £6.99 price tag may at first appear quite steep, believe me, the hours of fun you will get out of this game makes it all worthwhile.

Posted: April 13, 2012
												This game is a rare indy gem, unlike most indie gems, this game has more gameplay in it than most games released these days. The story is laughable and hard to follow, something about upgrading your mothership and getting a laser or something, but it does take a pretty unexpected twist in the fourth act. The meat of the game is VERY customizable ship combat. Outfit your increasingly powerful ships with lasers, cannons, missles, fighter drones, and more. The combat is great too, the Shield/Hull defences vs. Lasers/Projectiles mechanic requires carefull weapon loadouts, and as long as you keep your less than stellar AI comrades under a good leash, even overwhelming odds can be handled with skill. Also, SPAZ is made by a two-man team who are just doing what they love, and buying this game helps them make the game better. SPAZ has added HUGE amounts of content since launch (Namely the Bounty Hunters) and will keep having content added if people keep supporting it.

												Love games of this style, and glad to see one so well done. Posted: January 21, 2016
												This game fulfilled my dream of becoming a space pirate. The controls are engaging, the world convincing, the physics satisfying (ship explosions!), the story amusing, the space battles epic, and the graphics pleasing to the eye. Downsides are: the world is immense, but largely homogeneous - the gameplay becomes repetitive after a time. In the challenging systems, if you take a hard hit in a battle, it can take a while to recoup your lost resources. The ship and fleet customization is enjoyable, but there are only a couple missions that require particular kinds of builds. All in all, lot's of great fun to be had for the space pirate at heart, or the person that doesn't yet know they're a space pirate.

Posted: December 28, 2011
												Watch the trailer. If you like what you see, buy it. SPAZ is simply THE best game of it's genre, touching upon all the niche's and features that you might think to add to a top-down space exploration shmup. The Bounty Hunters update added a half dozen more ships and a ton of (voluntary) challenge scenarios.My biggest complaint: the second chapter (four chapters total) is rather long if you're a completionist and want to unlock everything. A lot of people stop playing prematurely and never enter the third chapter, where the zombies appear in earnest.Also: play on a medium sized galaxy. In a small galaxy the level gap between stars can be too large and you'll run out of things to do in a system, and you're more screwed if you♥♥♥♥♥♥off the wrong faction in a particular system. In a huge galaxy there's too many systems between you and wherever you want to go, so it gets repetitive.

Posted: January 21, 2016
												This game fulfilled my dream of becoming a space pirate. The controls are engaging, the world convincing, the physics satisfying (ship explosions!), the story amusing, the space battles epic, and the graphics pleasing to the eye. Downsides are: the world is immense, but largely homogeneous - the gameplay becomes repetitive after a time. In the challenging systems, if you take a hard hit in a battle, it can take a while to recoup your lost resources. The ship and fleet customization is enjoyable, but there are only a couple missions that require particular kinds of builds. All in all, lot's of great fun to be had for the space pirate at heart, or the person that doesn't yet know they're a space pirate.

Posted: February 11, 2013
												For a 2-man indie development team, one would not think that SPAZ could amount to much. Anyone thinking this: Boy were you wrong. SPAZ is a top-down, 2-D space-based shooter that combine RPG, RTS and some two-point elements to combine into a great, trully awesome game.At the time of writing this I have not beat it yet, but I have however sunk over 70 hours into it and really enjoyed myself. The game provides a plot and a purpose to strive for, but you get to chose how you get there. What ships you use, how you equip them, what tactics you employ, where you go, who you befriend/betray/fight, it's all up to you.If you enjoy Sci-Fi and shooters and a simple but great game with a rather twisted, grim-dark universe, all for the low price of 9 EURO's that don't demand a monster of a gaming PC, this is for you.

Posted: November 26, 2016
												What a game, what a work of art for a two-person team.It's so beautiful, from the debris-strewn starscapes to the twinkling spaceships and spinning starbases. The sound effects are good, too. The background chatter could have used more variety, but it was so well done and unobstrusive that it never annoyed me. The misanthropic humor is pervasive throughout the game, from the main characters' dialogue to the way slavery is tacitly endorsed by everyone.There are lots intriguing ships, weapons, and upgrades to try, though brute-force lasering was how I usually settled things. The beams-cannons-missiles damage system makes you carefully weigh your strengths and weaknesses, while the rez-goons-data economy keeps you hunting for ways to exploit and score. I would have liked more missions and factions, though.The difficulty of the game is quite well balanced until the very end. I got stuck many times, but getting unstuck often required just a different fleet or loadout. And when I needed a break, I could look for other things to do like collect components or free up warp gates.Still, the game is undeniably a grind. With there being only two factions and not much in the way of plot and missions, there is a lot of looking for other things to do. When the game got too repetitive, I'd play it intensely for a few weeks and then stop for a few months before playing again.What bothers me most is how the game ended. In the last chapter, I did the minimum I had to do to proceed to the finale. I then saved the game and went ahead to the finale just to take a brief peek at it, expecting to be defeated right away. Fifteen minutes later, I'd won the game without breaking a sweat. That was really disappointing. I was playing on Normal difficulty with a tech level of 113, so I don't think I was overleveled. In fact, the unique side missions were still very tough for me. Even the story, which I found fairly interesting, ended flatly.

Posted: November 26, 2016
												Don't let the stupid name put you off (as it did me), SPAZ is an awesome game. Check the demo to see for yourself.The game is a top down space ship fleet combat shooter. You design ships using modular components such as hulls, weapons, engines and other support systems that you unlock as you go. You can have multiple ships in your fleet but you only control one ship at a time with the ability to switch control to any combat ship in your fleet. You can give basic instructions to your other AI controlled ships via a tactical interface. Story wise it's pretty simplistic, with the occasional bit of juvenile humour. You travel around the galaxy gaining favour in star systems in order to unlock new technologies and access to services and resources.

Posted: July 19, 2013
												I blame a friend of mine for getting me to play this. I have had a lot of random fun just blasting stuff all across the stars. You can be a nice pirate, an evil pirate, or just flip flop depending on how much of an♥♥♥♥♥you want to be at the time. Killed a lot of time in this game indeedUpdating the Review affter time:This game is worth it. See above for some of the stuff I did. But, it's a classic at this point, and while there is a second game, the second game completely takes what most everyone loved of this game and gutted it. If you want a crazy yet engaging story, some silly dialogue, and a fun combat system, this is for you. The other fun is that each playthrough changes the galaxy you play in, randomizing a lot of things. Makes it a much more "roguelike" style.The only negative is that sometimes there's some grind for some resources if you want to get some things, but really, it's up to you on how you play, so if you want to grind to be overly powerful, or risk it all and go underpowered, that's your choice.

Posted: February 26, 2015
												Awesome gameplay, great story and an amazing RPG. Fight bandits, civilians or the UTA, collect REZ (money currency), level yourself and research ship upgrades, destroy ships to collect ship data to research and unlock ships, research upgrades for your ship(s), the possibilities are endless. Huge galaxy with many, many stars as well. Small grind, yes, but it is honestly worth the time and effort. Deal with repeatable quests, with the result of gaining a lot of experience (data), rez and increased reputation with a specific faction whilst losing reputation with another faction. Graphically, Spaz is very nice to look at.

Posted: January 19, 2015
												This is probably the grindiest game I've ever played. It's not a bad game at all, but it has a few hours of fun gameplay spread out over 25 hours repeating the same missions over and over. There's no real reason to explore systems, especially if you don't need a technology upgrade. A little blip of story in random systems or random FTL-style encounter would make it more compelling to explore.The devs in the forums confirm that the best way to play is to put all of your points into one type of weapon. If you don't, you'll have to grind 2-3x as much to viably use multiple types of weapons. Despite all the fancy looking weapons, attachments, and mounting points in this game, you'll probably end up with a ship loaded with all of one type of weapon. You'll also quickly learn to never die so much that you run out of rez, or you'll have to grind away at a mining station for a while just to have enough money to start playing the game again.If I played again, I would play without bounty hunters. It looks like they a balancing mechanism, because the only thing they do is provide a constant drain on your resources. The diminishing returns of their arena-style missions weren't very worthwhile.It does look very good, especially when battles involve different kinds of ships, weapons, and drones flying about. The movement and turning speed plays a major role in the game, so I did like how I feels like naval warfare. Throughout the 25 hours there were fun bits unlocking new ships and figuring out what works well too, but once I figured it out it was back to the grind. It's a decent game to play while watching TV or listening to some podcasts, but it wouldn't hold my interest alone.

Along the way research your own tech, customize your ships, and laugh as you ram your ship into the poor hapless crewmen from the ship you just made into space swiss cheese.  The fact that the story is voiced by the popular Youtubeist 'Totalbiscuit' is just icing on the cake.  SPAZ is truly a gem with an art style from games they just don't make any more.

Posted: August 24, 2015
												A little slow at first, but once you get your first few blueprints for new ships, the amount of customziation you can do is amazing!Fun top-down space shooter, a blend of space invaders, battletech, and Duke Nukem [the humor]. The grahics are both fun, and don't seem to get old very fast. Space shooter plus customizable space craft & tech tree to support your particular playstyle. Like missles or lazers? Want to use mega-bombers, or carriers with a small fleet of its own craft? You get to decide which ships to build in your 'home base', how they are armed, etc.Well worth the price.

Posted: December 29, 2011
												Space Pirats and Zombies is a fantastic achievement in of itself.  Its in the same vein as the old Star Control games in that it features an entirely "Top Down" perspective space combat experience. Despite what may seem like a straight forward simple game at first glance will quickly be washed away by how massive the galaxy can be if you so choose.SPAZ sports an intuitive levelling system where you earn points to spend on research to boost the attributes of several systems of your ships. From shields to turrets to the crew itself, the inner workings of your vessels will be fine tuned as you grow. Where you choose to research also determines what higher quality systems you will be able to implement as you acquire various blueprints for more efficient arms and armors. I would highly recommend this game to any and all who enjoy space combat. Its very action packed and exciting, at least in my opinion.It is truly the triumph of a motivated two man development team!

Posted: July 25, 2015
												This game is 90% great and 10% rubbish.  Its great when everything is going smoothly and you're rampaging around the galaxy killing stuff and its terrible when you get a certain map with an AI ship (in one of the fastest ships in the game) that shoots at you for a bit then runs off when it is near death, then comes back and shoots you again before running off.  When you have done this for 10 mins straight you will hate this game as much as I do - however, with a bit of patience you will realise that you can re-fit your ships mid-match to allow you to catch the tricky bugger or use drones which are faster than most ships.  .

I loved them immensely, so when I had a chance to pick this up, I said, why not? I still recall the first day I played it, I got into it a bit, then got dragged down to the pool by my little sister, then a thunderstorm started up, and I came back home and kept playing. How many games can you recall specifically the day you started playing?

Posted: January 13, 2013
												SPAZ is not your typical space shooter.  Think: Homeworld meets Command and Conquer.   Randomly generate your own galaxy to conquer, support the faction of your choice, and later destroy the zombie menace.  Along the way research your own tech, customize your ships, and laugh as you ram your ship into the poor hapless crewmen from the ship you just made into space swiss cheese.  The fact that the story is voiced by the popular Youtubeist 'Totalbiscuit' is just icing on the cake.  SPAZ is truly a gem with an art style from games they just don't make any more.

Posted: February 20
												A very fun game.The player has a space carrier in this game. The carrier usually jumps into a hidden position when jumping into a new system, and launches his smaller ships. The player commands one of the smaller ships, while the other are ai controlled.There are a lot of missions, mining possibilites and upgrades in each new star system. The whole galaxy has about 200 or more star systems. The game options allow it to set the size of the galaxy at the start of the game.The game follows a main story with a lot of side stories and random missions.
